[Plug] Tonight at Capitol Theatre: "When Dinosaurs Ruled the Earth", MST3K-style, with live commentary from Bill Squire and the Cleveland Museum of Natural History!
WRITING.TEXT:
[When Dinosaurs Ruled The Earth - MST3K-style!](http://clevelandcinemas.com/movie/232455/When-Dinosaurs-Ruled-The-Earth-Trailer-and-Info)
**Tonight, 7:00 PM at the Capitol Theatre on W 65th!**
Come watch this campy 1970's caveman flick featuring live commentary by Cleveland's own [Bill Squire](http://www.billsquire.com/) of the Alan Cox Show, and Lee Gambol (Distance Learning Coordinator) and Lee Hall (Vertebrate Paleontologist) of the Cleveland Museum of Natural History! This is the final [REEL Science](https://www.cmnh.org/reelscience) event until fall, so be sure not to miss it!
Interesting read. We certainly have the capacity to align ourselves with new industries, and the "brain gain" that NE Ohio has been enjoying lately makes me hopeful.

[Members' Behind-the-Scenes Night at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History](https://www.cmnh.org/calendar/member-behind-the-scenes-night)
Join us for an exclusive evening on Thursday, May 4 from 5:30 to 8:30pm FREE with your current membership. Engage with curators and staff, explore fascinating labs and collections, and peek into some of the research done behind-the-scenes every day. Youll also have the opportunity to see our latest traveling exhibition from the American Museum of Natural History, Amazing Species: Life at the Limits. Enjoy a cold treat courtesy of Mitchell's Ice Cream, or get dinner from Exploration: a Zack Bruell Restaurant, located off our Wade Oval Lobby.
Email membership@cmnh.org with the number of member tickets needed to be added to a wait list.
Attendees must bring their member card and ID for entry.
Complimentary parking in the Museum garage.

**When Dinosaurs Ruled The Earth - MST3K-style!**
[7 PM at the Capitol Theatre on W 65th!](http://clevelandcinemas.com/movie/232455/When-Dinosaurs-Ruled-The-Earth-Trailer-and-Info)
Come watch this campy 70's caveman flick with live commentary by Cleveland's own [Bill Squire](http://www.billsquire.com/) of the Alan Cox Show, and Lee Gambol (Distance Learning Coordinator) and Lee Hall (Vertebrate Paleontologist) of the Cleveland Museum of Natural History! This is the final [REEL Science](https://www.cmnh.org/reelscience) event of the season!

The March for Science is a grassroots effort meant to celebrate the important role science has played and continues to play in our lives. It is a family-friendly, non-partisan event for *everyone*: moms and dads, kids...everyone can come out and support science! See the event information below!
**Important Links**
[Program Info](http://www.sciencemarchcle.com/program.html)
[Speaker Bios](http://www.sciencemarchcle.com/speakers.html)
[Free Cleveland-themed Science Posters](http://www.sciencemarchcle.com/posters.html)
**ACTIVITIES - 9:00AM 10:00AM**
**South side of Public Square**
* Science-themed face paint and temporary tattoos
* Make your own bow ties in honor of Bill Nye the Science Guy
* Share your enthusiasm for science on banners to be carried during the March
* Test pH levels of different water samples
* Learn about endangered species
* Check your pulse rate before and after vigorous activity
* Take our taste test challenge! Can you guess the flavor of a jelly bean while blindfolded and plugging your nose?
Sponsored tables from the Cleveland Museum of the Natural History, Great Lakes Science Center, Greater Cleveland Aquarium, Holden Forests and Gardens, Ursuline College, Cleveland State University, Science Cafe, and Lake Erie College
**RALLY - 10:00AM - 11:00AM**
Speaker Program: Speaker Bios
* Introduction: Dr. Patricia Princehouse and Mr. Mrti Krbs (Co-Directors, March for Science Cleveland)
* Ms. Leslie Cuellar Vite (Graduate student, CWRU)
* Dr. Aparna Bole (Pediatrician, University Hospitals Rainbow Babies Childrens Hospital UH Sustainability Manager)
* Dr. Evalyn Gates (Director and CEO, Cleveland Museum of Natural History)
* Mr. Paul R. Abbey (Interim CEO, Holden Forests and Gardens)
* Dr. Hazel Marie (Professor and Chair of Mechanical Engineering, Youngstown State University)
* Keynote: Dr. Emmitt Jolly (Associate Professor, Department of Biology, Case Western Reserve University)
Speaking stage is the elevated area on the south side of Public Square between the Sailors and Soldiers Monument and Rebol Restaurant.
**MARCH - 11:00AM - 1:00PM**
Route is 1.2 miles.
* Start on south end of Public Square
* West on Superior to W 3rd
* North of W 3rd to Lakeside
* East of Lakeside to E 6th
* South of E 6th to Rockwell
* West on Rockwell to Ontario
* Back to south side of Public Square
-- Please follow the approved route to reduce bottlenecks and security risks --
**LOCATIONS**
**RALLY LOCATION**
* Stage: On south side of Public Square.
* Portable Restrooms: West side of South Public Square

WRITING.TITLE: Free Cleveland-themed science posters from the March for Science: Cleveland. Feel free to share, download, print and post! March for Science is Saturday, April 22 at Public Square. All are welcome!

WRITING.TEXT:
Tonight, April 12, at **7pm**
Capitol Theatre, 1390 W. 65 St, Cleveland OH 44102
Looking for something fun to do tonight? The CMNH's Department of Vertebrate Paleontology will be at Capitol Theatre for a trip to the depths of the Amazonian jungle, where a strange prehistoric beast lurks in the murky depths...in **3D**! There will be a unique display of real fossil specimens from the Devonian period, and you can enjoy a one-of-a-kind, fossil-filled introduction and post-film Q A with Curator of Vertebrate Paleontology Dr. Michael Ryan!
Good on you for helping out a helpless bird friend!

[CREATURE FROM THE BLACK LAGOON IN 3D (1954)](http://clevelandcinemas.com/movie/82893/Creature-from-the-Black-Lagoon-3D-Trailer-and-Info/20340)
**Wednesday, April 12; 7pm**
**Capitol Theatre, 1390 W. 65 St, Cleveland OH 44102**
Join the Cleveland Museum of Natural History's [Department of Vertebrate Paleontology](https://www.cmnh.org/vert-paleo/lab-members) at Capitol Theatre for a trip to the depths of the Amazonian jungle, where a strange prehistoric beast lurks in the murky depths! Check out a unique display of specimens from the paleontology collections, and enjoy a one-of-a-kind, fossil-filled introduction and post-film Q A with Curator of Vertebrate Paleontology Dr. Michael Ryan!
[About REEL Science](https://www.cmnh.org/reelscience)
**Cinema science vs. the facts**
Hollywood is known as the dream factorythe place where the best and brightest creative minds produce films that entertain, inspire and yeseven educate. But what happens when movie magic is made at the expense of scientific fact? Well watch films that tackle science on the silver screenfrom stoically serious blockbusters to outrageously campy cult classicsand hear from Museum experts as they put these movies under the microscope to determine what the filmmakers got right... and what is better classified as creative license. Join us on this sometimes shocking, often hilarious and always illuminating journey into Reel Science!
Reel Science takes place the first Wednesday of the month, from September through May, at a Cleveland Cinemas location.
Wow!

The Cleveland Museum of Natural History has a bunch of cool activities:
[Think and Drink with the Extinct](https://www.cmnh.org/visit/special-events/think-drink-with-the-extinct) - one Wednesday a month, the museum hosts an adult event with bars, food, and lots of activities and specimens set out that aren't normally on display! There is a featured brewery or distillery, too. Next up: Entomology, featuring beers by Platform Beer Co., April 19 from 5 - 9 PM!
[REEL Science](https://www.cmnh.org/reelscience) - watch old and new sci-fi flicks with scientists who bring in museum specimens and do Q A's about the science in the movies. Next up: Creature from the Black Lagoon, in 3D - April 12 at the Capitol Theater, 7 PM!

WRITING.TEXT: Good ol' Berea Sandstone!

Fun brings people in from out side temporarily, and brings young people here for college or even shorter periods of time, then they leave, this is not how a city is built unless of course you're Vegas ;). We are not...
A study from the Manhattan Institute says otherwise.
See this article: http://www.cleveland.com/architecture/index.ssf/2015/08/manhattan_institute_study_laud.html
"Brain Gain in America's Shrinking Cities," a new report by Aaron Renn, released today by the institute, lists Cleveland as one of 28 metro areas that experienced a double-digit percentage increase in residents with a bachelor's degree or higher between 2000 and 2013.
One reason for the solid performance by the Cleveland metro area is an increase in young, highly educated workers. Renn found that between 2000 and 2013, Cleveland-Elyria gained 7,650 adults between the ages of 25 and 34 with college degrees or higher, an 8.9 percent increase.
Cleveland is not only keeping young people with college degrees; it is gaining them.

You deserve way more up votes for this post.

Color can be misleading. Groundwater and mineral chemistry affects fossil color. They are certainly teeth of *C. megalodon*. One of the indicators is the prominent chevron or triangle shaped feature above the root. It's called a burlette.

WRITING.TITLE: The Wild and Scenic Film Festival is in Cleveland this Saturday!
WRITING.TEXT:
The festival is happening Saturday, March 11 at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History.
From the [museum's website](https://www.cmnh.org/wsff):
The Wild Scenic Film Festival is once again making a stop at the Museum as it tours the United States! See environmental and adventure films that illustrate the Earths beauty, the challenges facing our planet, and the work communities around the world are doing to protect the environment. $8 special event rate parking in the Museum garage after 2:30pm. Cash beer ($5) and wine ($6) bar starting at 5pm. Complimentary light snacks (popcorn, crudits, cranberry trail mix) from 6 to 9:30pm.
TICKETS Advance: $15 members; $20 nonmembers Day of: $20 members; $25 nonmembers
First Show Doors: 3pm. Films: 3:30-6:30pm. EnviroFair: 6-7:30pm.
Second Show Doors: 6pm. EnviroFair: 6-7:30pm. Films: 7:30-10:30pm.
For more information about the festival and its other stops across the nation:
https://www.wildandscenicfilmfestival.org/

Industrial runoff, agricultural runoff, iron in the water. Sewers emptied into the river pretty much unchecked in places. In the 1870's the mayor of Cleveland is quoted as saying the Cuyahoga was an open sewer flowing through the middle of the city. Today, thanks to the Clean Water Act, EPA, and Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District, and countless unsung activists and concerned citizens, the Cuyahoga is cleaner than it has been in nearly two centuries. It is full of many pollution-sensitive species that would not have survived in the river of this photo.
Nice snow band!

WRITING.TITLE: This is a 360 million-year-old fossil shark skull from Cleveland, Ohio. This species, Cladoselache, is older than flowering plants, which evolved in the Mesozoic after dinosaurs had taken hold of the earth.

WRITING.TITLE: Darwin Day Dinosaurs 7 pm tonight at the Euclid Tavern!

WRITING.TEXT:
Tonight at Euclid Tavern, celebrate Charles Darwin's birthday a few days early, and hear a paleontologist from the Cleveland Museum of Natural History talk about dinosaur tracks!
7 pm, Euclid Tavern near Case Western. Presented by the Institute for the Science of Origins.
https://www.facebook.com/events/1765351417050354/?ti=cl

From the website:
DISCOVERY DAY
Enjoy free general admission on Martin Luther King Jr. Day!
WHERE Cleveland Museum of Natural History, 1 Wade Oval Drive, Cleveland OH 44106
WHEN 1/16/2017 at 10:00 AM
PRICES Members: Free Non-members: Free
We're revving up for a great day of discovery! Visitors receive FREE general admission from 10am to 4pm on Monday, January 16. Curators will talk with guests outside of their labs and take out specimens that are not usually on display. Visitors can enjoy mini Shafran Planetarium shows for $1/person and participate in amazing demonstrations with scientists and students from Case Western Reserve University. Guests can meet Clevelands neighborhood wildlife in special live animal presentations, and make a craft to take home in Smead Discovery Center on the Museum's lower level.
The Rainey Chorus, featuring local children from 5 to 14 years of age, will give short performances at 11am and 12pm in Murch Auditorium. Their selections will honor Martin Luther King Jr., the Civil Rights Movement, and the season.
$10 flat rate parking in the Museum garage. University Circle, Inc. will provide free shuttle service to participating organizations. Parking will fill up fast! We recommend getting here early to beat the crowd.

WRITING.TITLE: *Free admission* at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History this coming Monday, January 16!
My, What a Big Mouth You Have: Studying Dunkleosteus jaws and the injuries they inflicted provide clues to a violent lifestyle.

WRITING.TEXT:
That thing is *Dunkleosteus terrelli*, the biggest, baddest predator of the Devonian ocean (360 million years ago), when Cleveland was under a 300 foot deep tropical sea and south of the equator.
Check out this article about the menacing jaws and brutal habits of this monster fish: [My, what a big mouth you have](https://www.cmnh.org/blog/january-2017/my-what-a-big-mouth-you-have)

Ice crystals are indeed a mineral. They have a classified crystal system based on the water molecule, and a characteristic chemical formula: H2O. Look it up on any mineral website or mineralogy textbook and you will see that ice is a mineral just as surely as quartz, copper, iron, plagioclase, hornblende, muscovite, or enstatite. Snowflakes *are* euhedral mineral crystals. I'm not making this up.
See:
http://www.minerals.net/mineral/ice.aspx
http://academic.emporia.edu/abersusa/go336/merhoff/
In geology, sediments are accumulations of individual rock and mineral particles. Sedimentation, the process of sediment accumulation, involves the transport of rock and mineral fragments in a fluid, followed by their subsequent deposition. Those fluids include liquid water and atmospheric gases, or air.
Sediments are sorted and classified first by particle *size*, then by particle *composition*. Sand is a sediment type defined as rock and mineral grains larger than silt and smaller than gravel. More precisely, particles having a diameter between 1/16 of a millimeter up to 2.0 millimeters. Geologists use a standardized scale, called the Phi Scale, to classify particles into a sediment group.
See:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grain_size
http://www.planetary.org/multimedia/space-images/charts/wentworth-1922-grain-size.html
Putting all this together: Ice crystals are deposited in large accumulations during sedimentation events controlled by planetary atmospheric conditions. Ice crystals are mineral grains. As minerals they fall under the regime of geologic nomenclature. Ice crystals fall into the 'sand' and 'granule' particle size range of the Phi Scale.
Science has nothing to do with it. You're saying: 1. Snow is minerals. 2. Sand is minerals. 3. Therefore, snow is sand. That is a logical fallacy.
It's all about science. I'm saying: 1. Ice crystals (snow) are indeed mineral crystals. 2. Sand is a size classification for rock and mineral particles. 3. Ice crystals fall under the sand and granule size range. That is a demonstrable scientific fact.
Sand is just a word that describes a particle size for rocks and minerals. Sand isn't just quartz grains at the beach. Look up garnet sand. Or shell sand. Or basalt sand. Calcium carbonate sand. Oolitic sand. Coral sand. Gypsum sand. Glass sand. Volcanic ash, etc., etc.
Say what you want about logic. This is science.

WRITING.TITLE: Snowflakes are mineral crystals. Sand is an accumulation of minerals and rock particles smaller than gravel but larger than silt. Therefore, snow is a type of sand that rains from the sky.

There are many things to do outdoors in winter especially within Cleveland Metroparks. Come outside and sample a few winter activities. WRITING.TITLE: Season's Eatings! Who ever said that paleontologists don't know how to have fun? Also: "Nanotyrannus" skull! [Fossil Pic]
Season's Eatings! Who says paleontologists don't know how to have a little fun now and again?
Paleontologists examining sauropod trackways have discovered new evidence about the use of their massive claws. [article]
Paleontologists have uncovered new evidence about the function of sauropod claws by studying well-preserved fossil trackways.

WRITING.TEXT:
Also featured on [WKYC's 6 things to do this weekend in Cleveland](http://www.wkyc.com/news/local/six-things-to-do-this-weekend-in-northeast-ohio-nov-12-13/350869022), Dinofest takes place at the [Cleveland Museum of Natural History](https://www.cmnh.org/).
This year, an amazing roster of dinosaur experts will be speaking on topics like reproductive behavior in the raptor-like dinosaur *Troodon formosus*, recreating cretaceous ecosystems using paleoecology, how *T. rex* grew up and transformed from a fleet-footed rebel to a titanic, 40-foot predator, and how artists reconstruct extinct animals and bring them to life in paintings. There will also be a workshop where you can learn to draw dinosaurs with famed paleoartist [Dr. Julius Csotonyi](http://csotonyi.com/).
The museum will also have special fossils on display for you to see and touch, and lots of family-friendly activities set up around the museum- like fossil casting, and fossil dig activities.
The speaker roster includes:
Dr. David Varricchio from Montana State University
Dr. Holly Woodward-Ballard from Oklahoma State University
Dr. Jordan Mallon from the Canadian Museum of Nature
Dr. Julius Csotonyi, paleo artist extraordinaire
This is all included in the cost of admission for the museum, so check it out!

WRITING.TITLE: Saturday, paleontologists from across North America are descending on Cleveland for the 3rd annual Dinofest!
